::: {style="font-size:1.4rem; line-height:1.5; margin:0 auto;"}
In this document, we will take you through the demographic, socioeconomic, and health profiles of communities in Western Sydney from 2011 to 2021.
:::

<br>

![](images/wslhd_cover_map.png){width=100%}

<br>

::: {style="font-size:2.0rem; line-height:1.5;"}
**Acknowledgement**
:::

::: {style="font-size:1.4rem; line-height:1.5; margin:0 auto;"}
We acknowledge the Traditional Custodians of the lands on which the communities of WSLHD live, gather, and work.

We pay our deepest respects to Elders past and present, who have cared for this Country for countless generations and continue to uphold cultural knowledge, identity, and connection to land.

We also extend this respect to all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples who engage with this work, and recognise their enduring contributions to community health, wellbeing, and cultural heritage.
:::

<br>

::: {style="font-size:2.0rem; line-height:1.5;"}
**Data Sources**
:::

::: {style="font-size:1.4rem; line-height:1.5; margin:0 auto;"}
The analysis is based on Census data from 2011 and 2021, accessed through the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) TableBuilder.
:::

<br>

::::::::{.cr-section layout="overlay-left"}

To start with the analysis, let’s begin with a brief introduction to WSLHD. @cr-metro-map-1

This is a partial map of New South Wales, Australia. @cr-metro-map-1

:::{#cr-metro-map-1}
![](images/metro_map_1.png){style="width:100%; height:100%; object-fit:contain; border-radius:0"}
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-metro-map-2"}

Let’s turn our attention to the areas outlined in purple. These represent the 6 [**NSW Metropolitan Local Health Districts**]{style="color: #A56ACF;"}:

- Nepean Blue Mountains
- Northern Sydney
- South Eastern Sydney
- South Western Sydney
- Sydney
- Western Sydney

:::

These 6 LHDs form the healthcare network of metropolitan NSW, providing health services to the people living in this region. @cr-metro-map-2

:::{#cr-metro-map-2 .viz}
![](images/metro_map_2.png){style="width:100%; height:100%; object-fit:contain; border-radius:0"}
:::

The orange area represents [**WSLHD**]{style="color: #F59E0B;"}, recognised as a leader in clinical care, research, and education across Western Sydney. @cr-metro-map-3

Let’s take a closer look at the population shifts in metropolitan NSW from 2011 to 2021. @cr-metro-map-3

:::{#cr-metro-map-3 .viz}
![](images/metro_map_3.png){style="width:100%; height:100%; object-fit:contain; border-radius:0"}
:::

::::::::


::::::::{.cr-section layout="sidebar-right"}

According to 2011 Census, around **4.14 million** people lived in the metropolitan region, accounting for about **60%** of the entire NSW population. @cr-metro-pop-1

:::{#cr-metro-pop-1}
![](images/metro_pop_1.png){fig-align="left" style="width:95%; height:50%; border-radius:0"}
:::

By 2021, that metropolitan population had grown to almost **5 million**, accounting for more than 60% of the entire NSW population. [@cr-metro-pop-2]{style="display:block; margin-left:-2rem"}

:::{#cr-metro-pop-2}
![](images/metro_pop_2.png){fig-align="left" style="width:95%; height:50%; border-radius:0"}
:::

Western Sydney and South Western Sydney alone each passed the milestone of 1 million residents. @cr-metro-pop-3

**Western Sydney’s population growth rate alone has reached closely 30%.**
[@cr-metro-pop-3]{scale-by="4" pan-to="-80%, 150%"}

:::{#cr-metro-pop-3}
![](images/metro_pop_3.png){fig-align="left" style="width:95%; height:50%; border-radius:0"}
:::


Next, let’s break down the metropolitan region in more detail. @cr-metro-pop-4

:::{focus-on="cr-metro-pop-4"}

Each [**Local Health District**]{style="color: #439755;"} can be mapped using Statistical Area Level 2 (SA2) boundaries. 

<br>

Defined by the ABS, an SA2 represents a community where people live, work, and interact socially and economically. 

<br>

While SA2s do not always fit neatly within a single LHD, together they provide a useful way to examine communities at a smaller geographic scale. @cr-metro-pop-4

:::

We calculated population growth rates by SA2. From this, we discovered that… @cr-metro-pop-4

:::{#cr-metro-pop-4}
![](images/metro_pop_4.png){fig-align="left" style="width:95%; height:50%; border-radius:0"}
:::


We identified [**high-grwoth SA2s**]{style="color: #F59E0B;"} with growth rate exceeding 100%. @cr-metro-pop-5

Also, we found that most of [**high-grwoth SA2s**]{style="color: #F59E0B;"} are concentrated in Western Sydney.
[@cr-metro-pop-5]{scale-by="3" pan-to="-100%, -62%"}

Next, we focus  on the [**high-grwoth SA2s**]{style="color: #F59E0B;"} within Western Sydney.
[@cr-metro-pop-5]{scale-by="3" pan-to="-100%, -62%"}

:::{#cr-metro-pop-5}
![](images/metro_pop_5.png){fig-align="left" style="width:95%; height:50%; border-radius:0"}
:::

:::{focus-on="cr-metro-pop-6"}

Back in 2011, their populations were all under 10,000. Over just ten years, these communities grew at an extraordinary pace. 

<br>

This rapid change signals that WSLHD is full of fascinating and valuable patterns for us to explore... @cr-metro-pop-6

:::


:::{#cr-metro-pop-6}
![](images/metro_pop_6.png){fig-align="left" style="width:95%; height:50%; border-radius:0"}
:::

::::::::
